post_text: Congratulations Ms. Stipes and all of our awesome educators! Read more: www.btcs.org/about_us/what_s_new/rotary_teacher_awards
text: Congratulations Ms. Stipes and all of our awesome educators! Read more: www.btcs.org/about_us/what_s_new/rotary_teacher_awards

post_text: If you missed it, congratulations are in order to Fairmount Elementary School's April Stipes for winning this year's Rotary Outstanding Teacher Award for BTCS. Ms. Stipes earned a $3,000 cash award, a $1,000 donation to her school, and a circulating plaque for display at her school. In addition, we would like to congratulate the following teachers who also earned nominations: Shannon Morey, Avoca; Christine Booher, Anderson; Jennifer Hawthorne, Haynesfield; Tammy Chandler, Holston View; Michelle Phillips, Tennessee High; and Whitney Maddox, Vance Middle. Each of these amazing educators earned a $500 cash award! Awards were also given to educators with Bristol Virginia Public Schools. Thank you to Rotary Club of Bristol VA-TN and Bristol Tennessee Essential Services for making these recognitions possible!

In addition, we would like to congratulate the following teachers who also earned nominations: Shannon Morey, Avoca; Christine Booher, Anderson; Jennifer Hawthorne, Haynesfield; Tammy Chandler, Holston View; Michelle Phillips, Tennessee High; and Whitney Maddox, Vance Middle. Each of these amazing educators earned a $500 cash award! Awards were also given to educators with Bristol Virginia Public Schools. Thank you to Rotary Club of Bristol VA-TN and Bristol Tennessee Essential Services for making these recognitions possible!

post_text: Thank you, Sturdy-Lite and our other grant partners! Many THS students will benefit from the new welding program.
shared_text:
Tennessee High School is at Tennessee High School.
August 11 at 9:07 PM · Bristol, TN ·

Sturdy-Lite has partnered with BTCS to begin a new welding program at Tennessee High! Today, Sturdy-Lite presented a donation check for over $5,600 to purchase a Millermatic 350P welding machine. Our new welding teacher, Jeff Simcox, has been instrumental in getting the program underway.

A Perkins Reserve Regional Career Pathways grant, as well as a Secondary grant, provided the funds needed for equipment, supplies, and resources to begin the new program of study in welding. Grant partnerships include Sturdy-Lite, TCAT (TN College of Applied Tech.)--Elizabethton, Northeast State, Bristol Essential Services (BTES), and United Way of Bristol. These grants will be used to start five new CTE programs of study at Tennessee High School: Cybersecurity, Teaching as a Profession, Hospitality & Tourism, Sport & Human Performance, and Welding.
text:
Thank you, Sturdy-Lite and our other grant partners! Many THS students will benefit from the new welding program.

Tennessee High School is at Tennessee High School.
August 11 at 9:07 PM · Bristol, TN ·

Sturdy-Lite has partnered with BTCS to begin a new welding program at Tennessee High! Today, Sturdy-Lite presented a donation check for over $5,600 to purchase a Millermatic 350P welding machine. Our new welding teacher, Jeff Simcox, has been instrumental in getting the program underway.

A Perkins Reserve Regional Career Pathways grant, as well as a Secondary grant, provided the funds needed for equipment, supplies, and resources to begin the new program of study in welding. Grant partnerships include Sturdy-Lite, TCAT (TN College of Applied Tech.)--Elizabethton, Northeast State, Bristol Essential Services (BTES), and United Way of Bristol. These grants will be used to start five new CTE programs of study at Tennessee High School: Cybersecurity, Teaching as a Profession, Hospitality & Tourism, Sport & Human Performance, and Welding.

post_text:
If you have an upcoming 5th grader interested in becoming a part of our Elementary Band program for the 2020-20201 school year, please complete the form linked below! Band classes will be offered for both remote and on-site learners! Band classes will take place on the Canvas platform when we are in remote learning. We will be adapting any in-person band classes to meet health and safety requirements surrounding COVID-19.

And remember, you don't have to have any prior musical training to join band! We start with the basics and will teach you everything you need to know!

Informational video for BTCS Elementary Band:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KmbFUwDhs78&feature=youtu.be

Form for 5th graders interested in joining band: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScgS49Dkcr55TVY4Wwp9kLDgaXj6L7l5CdQ2PghYs3wzBVT4Q/viewform

post_text: Due to the increased need for teacher professional development, the Bristol Tennessee Board of Education approved a revised school calendar for the 2020-2021 school year. post_text: Since the release of the Framework for Opening the 2020-21 School Year: Sullivan County Plan and our survey asking parents to choose the academic pathway for their child, we have received numerous questions from parents. Also since that time, the case count of COVID-19 in our community has risen significantly resulting in further evaluation of the most practical health and safety protocol for students and staff. A few updates have been made to the FAQ online, and we are preparing even more information for parents for release tomorrow. We are extending the deadline to complete the Academic Pathway Choice survey until Wednesday, July 15, to give parents time to review the new information prior to making a decision.
text: Since the release of the Framework for Opening the 2020-21 School Year: Sullivan County Plan and our survey asking parents to choose the academic pathway for their child, we have received numerous questions from parents. Also since that time, the case count of COVID-19 in our community has risen significantly resulting in further evaluation of the most practical health and safety protocol for students and staff. A few updates have been made to the FAQ online, and we are preparing even more information for parents for release tomorrow. We are extending the deadline to complete the Academic Pathway Choice survey until Wednesday, July 15, to give parents time to review the new information prior to making a decision.

post_text: Please see the important announcement below regarding prom.
shared_text:
Tennessee High School
July 13 at 5:32 PM ·

Since last week’s communication about prom, the COVID-19 case counts in Sullivan County have risen significantly. According to officials with the Sullivan County Health Department, the case numbers are expected to continue to trend upward. As such, we have made the difficult decision to cancel our 2020 Prom. For students who have already purchased tickets, a full refund will be issued to the card used in the transaction. Please allow up to three days for the refund to be processed.

At this time, graduation is still scheduled as planned. The format and space available for graduation make it easier to put social distancing safety measures in place, although it may be necessary to further limit the number of guests allowed per graduate. In addition, face coverings will be required by attendees as outlined in Sullivan County Executive Order One issued on July 10. We will provide additional updates about graduation as needed. www.tinyurl.com/thsclassof2020.

post_text: Bristol Tennessee City Schools is excited to welcome Dr. Blair Henley as our new chief technology officer. For the past nine years, Dr. Henley has served as vice-president of information services and chief technology officer at Tusculum University. He was also the director of technology for the Niswonger Foundation’s Northeast College and Career Ready Consortium from 2010-2018. Dr. Henley is a familiar face at BTCS as he served as the CTE director and assistant principal at Tennessee High School from 2003 to 2011. He has extensive teaching experience at both the high school and college levels.

He has extensive teaching experience at both the high school and college levels.

post_text:
Bristol Tennessee City Schools is excited to announce new principal appointments for the 2020-2021 school year. Tanika Hardin, program assistant at Haynesfield Elementary School, has been named as the new principal of Haynesfield. Jeremy Humphrey, assistant principal at Elizabethton High School, has been named principal of Tennessee Online Public School.

Ms. Hardin has 16 years of experience as an educator at the elementary and middle school levels, with 13 of those with BTCS. She has served in her role as program assistant at Haynesfield for the past four years. Mr. Humphrey currently serves as an assistant principal at Elizabethton High School, a position he has held since 2018. Prior to becoming a secondary administrator, he taught high school math for nine years.

Congratulations and welcome!
text:
Bristol Tennessee City Schools is excited to announce new principal appointments for the 2020-2021 school year. Tanika Hardin, program assistant at Haynesfield Elementary School, has been named as the new principal of Haynesfield. Jeremy Humphrey, assistant principal at Elizabethton High School, has been named principal of Tennessee Online Public School.

Ms. Hardin has 16 years of experience as an educator at the elementary and middle school levels, with 13 of those with BTCS. She has served in her role as program assistant at Haynesfield for the past four years. Mr. Humphrey currently serves as an assistant principal at Elizabethton High School, a position he has held since 2018. Prior to becoming a secondary administrator, he taught high school math for nine years.

Congratulations and welcome!

REMINDER! 𝑷𝒂𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒕 𝑺𝒖𝒓𝒗𝒆𝒚-𝑺𝒄𝒉𝒐𝒐𝒍 𝑹𝒆𝒐𝒑𝒆𝒏𝒊𝒏𝒈: www.surveymonkey.com/r/Y7YBR7R

As we plan for the opening of the 2020-2021 school year on August 3, the leaders of Bristol Tennessee City Schools are committed to two primary goals: protecting the health and safety of students and staff and providing a high-quality education for all students in our district. To best achieve these goals, we are using all available resources, seeking advice, and gathering feedback from a wide variety of stakeholders. While there will be few simple solutions, it is important to us to honor the many viewpoints and opinions surrounding COVID-19 and any impact our plans may have on families and the broader community.

Please follow the link above to respond to a brief survey based on what you know and feel today about your child returning to school. Upon receiving survey results, we will update all stakeholders on the plan moving forward. The deadline to complete the survey is June 21. Thank you for your input!

If you have multiple children, please complete one survey per child.

post_text:
In light of school closures due to the outbreak of COVID-19, the Tennessee Department of Safety has temporarily modified their procedures for students to verify adequate academic progress and attendance in school. These procedures are necessary for students hoping to obtain a first-time driver’s license or seeking reinstatement after revocation due to a lack of adequate academic progress or attendance.

In lieu of verifying adequate academic progress and attendance, Department of Safety will temporarily require parents/guardians to certify, using the tn.gov form linked below, that their student’s school is closed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and therefore, their student is unable to obtain the required documentation necessary to verify adequate academic progress and attendance.
shared_text:
TN.GOV
www.tn.gov
text:
In light of school closures due to the outbreak of COVID-19, the Tennessee Department of Safety has temporarily modified their procedures for students to verify adequate academic progress and attendance in school. These procedures are necessary for students hoping to obtain a first-time driver’s license or seeking reinstatement after revocation due to a lack of adequate academic progress or attendance.

In lieu of verifying adequate academic progress and attendance, Department of Safety will temporarily require parents/guardians to certify, using the tn.gov form linked below, that their student’s school is closed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and therefore, their student is unable to obtain the required documentation necessary to verify adequate academic progress and attendance.

post_text: Here’s a great way to connect with others in the community and stay active this summer. River’s Way works throughout the year with BTCS students with physical and cognitive disabilities through gardening, Cafe Central, and other programs. Check out the link below to find out how you can join the walking challenge. Everyone is invited!
shared_text:
River's Way
May 26 at 12:03 PM ·

Did you know that you can support River's Way by WALKING???

Download the MapMyWalk App today, and search for Matt Kyle in friends (River's Way logo as picture). Matt will then invite you to our River's Way Walkers Challenge! Each time you take a walk using MapMyWalk, group members can like and comment on your walks. You can even share to social media and add pictures to your walks.

By joining our inclusive group, you are challenging yourself to improve your physical and mental health, while also motivating others to do the same. You are connecting with a movement of walkers that is bigger than yourself. Here are more detailed instructions on how to join:

https://www.riversway.org/river-s-way-walkers

post_text: Attention BTCS Families! The deadline has been extended until Wednesday, May 20! Get those rainbows in to win!
shared_text:
City of Bristol TN
May 1 at 10:01 AM ·

Children around the globe are putting rainbows in windows to spread cheer and remind us that we’re all in the fight against the coronavirus together. WHY RAINBOWS? Rainbows spread hope and are a sign of good things to come. The U.S. Census also provides HOPE FOR THE FUTURE by ensuring that federal tax dollars flow back to Bristol for such things as new roads, schools, emergency services, and more.

That's why we're inviting kids in our community to enter our COUNTING RAINBOWS COLORING CONTEST. The deadline to enter is 5 p.m. on May 15. Contest guidelines and a rainbow coloring sheet are available at https://www.bristoltn.org/1436/Counting-Rainbows

Let's decorate Bristol with colorful rainbows!

shared_text:
Tennessee High School
May 6 at 3:41 PM ·

On Monday & Tuesday, May 11 & 12, THS will have drive-thru dropoff and pickup set up in front of the school. Students can pick up items (yearbooks, Beta tassels, NHS stoles, etc.) & can also drop off items (librarby books, textbooks, uniforms, etc.). NHS members need to bring $22.25 to pay for their stoles. Seniors who no longer need their computers for a class will also return their chargers, laptops, & backpacks. Underclassmen will keep theirs until we return to school in August. Please scroll through the graphics for details and most importantly SCHEDULED HOMEROOM TIMES. Cars should have a homemade tag with student name and teacher homeroom name. Only students from the homerooms scheduled will be permitted to enter the line. There will be a makeup day on Wednesday from 10-2. Yearbooks will be sold on Wednesday on a first-come, first-serve basis, provided there are available copies.
text:
Tennessee High School
May 6 at 3:41 PM ·

On Monday & Tuesday, May 11 & 12, THS will have drive-thru dropoff and pickup set up in front of the school. Students can pick up items (yearbooks, Beta tassels, NHS stoles, etc.) & can also drop off items (librarby books, textbooks, uniforms, etc.). NHS members need to bring $22.25 to pay for their stoles. Seniors who no longer need their computers for a class will also return their chargers, laptops, & backpacks. Underclassmen will keep theirs until we return to school in August. Please scroll through the graphics for details and most importantly SCHEDULED HOMEROOM TIMES. Cars should have a homemade tag with student name and teacher homeroom name. Only students from the homerooms scheduled will be permitted to enter the line. There will be a makeup day on Wednesday from 10-2. Yearbooks will be sold on Wednesday on a first-come, first-serve basis, provided there are available copies.

post_text:
A message from Dr. Tudor:

First, let me begin by thanking you for quickly adjusting to a new normal in your home environment the past several weeks. I recognize the challenges you have faced as you took on the added responsibility of overseeing your child’s schoolwork while many of you had to work from home yourselves or simply adjust to staying home due to COVID-19. Thank you for all that you have done to support our teachers and school staff as they worked alongside you tirelessly providing learning opportunities for your child. 𝙔𝙤𝙪 𝙨𝙝𝙤𝙪𝙡𝙙 𝙖𝙡𝙨𝙤 𝙗𝙚 𝙘𝙚𝙡𝙚𝙗𝙧𝙖𝙩𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙬𝙚𝙚𝙠 𝙖𝙨 𝙬𝙚 𝙧𝙚𝙘𝙤𝙜𝙣𝙞𝙯𝙚 𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙩𝙚𝙖𝙘𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙨 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙨𝙩𝙖𝙛𝙛 𝙛𝙤𝙧 𝙉𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣𝙖𝙡 𝙏𝙚𝙖𝙘𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝘼𝙥𝙥𝙧𝙚𝙘𝙞𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣 𝙬𝙚𝙚𝙠.

As the school year is nearing its end, I wanted to provide you with additional details about upcoming plans for closing out the year. Read more: https://tinyurl.com/btcs9covid19.

post_text:
𝑾𝒆𝒍𝒄𝒐𝒎𝒆 𝑫𝒓. 𝑻𝒖𝒅𝒐𝒓! In a special called session tonight, the Bristol Tennessee Board of Education approved a contract for Dr. Annette Tudor to become the district's next director of schools. Dr. Tudor is currently serving for the second time as interim director for the district. Even though she is already providing tremendous leadership for our district, let's give an official BTCS welcome to Dr. Tudor! The four-year contract officially begins July 1 to align with the district's fiscal year. #WeAreBTCS
.

City of Bristol TN
April 29 at 12:01 PM ·

Don't forget the Sullivan County Regional Health Department is sponsoring drive-through COVID-19 testing tomorrow - Thursday, April 30 - at the Slater Community Center. This one-day-only testing will be conducted from 9 AM until Noon, and no appointment is necessary.

Testing BY APPOINTMENT is also available weekdays from 1-4 PM at the health department's Blountville office through May 1. Call 423-279-2777 to make an appointment or get more information.

post_text: Information for students in AP classes
shared_text:
Tennessee High School
April 22 at 4:32 PM ·

AP STUDENTS:

Info on Student Communications and Exam Access

You will need access to your email or College Board account to take the 2020 AP Exams.

1. Check the email address you used to create your account on myap.collegeboard.org . You should regularly check this email address for the most recent information about their AP Exams.

2. Verify your College Board account at myap.collegeboard.org by clicking on your profile at the top right-hand corner of the page and going to "Account Settings." Scroll down to verify your information, and confirm that your email address is the one to which you'd like to receive the e-ticket to take your AP Exams. If it's not the correct email,
update it to an email you check regularly by clicking "Update."

post_text: Good Monday Morning, BTCS! As we enter into another week of at-home learning for students, we want to remind you to be kind to yourself. Don't compare yourself to what the at-home learning activities look like for other families, especially in all the social media highlights out there. Remember, we are modeling to our kids that we don't have to strive for perfection or imitate what others are doing. This is not a competition! We are all on the same team! #WeAreBTCS

post_text: Wow, what a difference a month makes. Our classrooms, which are usually full of children actively engaged in learning, sit empty. Our teachers are getting more creative than ever before by connecting with students through technology and over the phone. Our school nutrition staff members are preparing meals and serving them from buses in 15 locations throughout our community, instead of in our seven lively cafeterias. But rest assured, the one thing that hasn’t changed through all of this is our spirit! #WeAreBTCS Read more of Dr. Tudor's letter: tinyurl.com/tudorletter4-6-2020

post_text: Here's something we need parents and guardians to know and do today ... First of all, acknowledge that this is an unprecedented and temporary moment. If you are concerned that your child is missing out on academic content, less is more at a time like this. We are all broadening our definitions of learning to focus more on playtime, downtime, and family time. Remember to BREATHE! #WeAreBTCS

post_text: Time to show off those art skills BTCS!
shared_text:
City of Bristol TN
March 30 at 6:00 PM ·

Great news for all you budding artists! We’re making it easier than ever to enter our 1st annual Easter Egg Art Contest. Decorate a real egg, create one out of cardboard or paper mache, paint one on canvas, or craft it from construction paper or cardboard. Use any materials and any medium you choose.

Next, take a digital picture and send it to parks&recfun@bristoltn.org. Include your name, age, grade and school (if applicable), address, and phone number. It’s that easy!

This contest is for community members of ALL AGES. Ribbons will be awarded to 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place winners in 7 age categories, and all 1st place winners will also receive a gift certificate to purchase cool items from the Bristol Merch Perch. Your egg-straordinary masterpiece may even be shared on the City’s website and social media platforms!

Don’t delay! The deadline to enter is Wednesday, April 8 at midnight.
text:
Time to show off those art skills BTCS!

City of Bristol TN
March 30 at 6:00 PM ·

Great news for all you budding artists! We’re making it easier than ever to enter our 1st annual Easter Egg Art Contest. Decorate a real egg, create one out of cardboard or paper mache, paint one on canvas, or craft it from construction paper or cardboard. Use any materials and any medium you choose.

Next, take a digital picture and send it to parks&recfun@bristoltn.org. Include your name, age, grade and school (if applicable), address, and phone number. It’s that easy!

This contest is for community members of ALL AGES. Ribbons will be awarded to 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place winners in 7 age categories, and all 1st place winners will also receive a gift certificate to purchase cool items from the Bristol Merch Perch. Your egg-straordinary masterpiece may even be shared on the City’s website and social media platforms!

Don’t delay! The deadline to enter is Wednesday, April 8 at midnight.

post_text:
It is with sadness that we have decided to cancel what would have been the 8th Annual Power of Play 5K on April 25, 2020. Each school is in the process of issuing refunds to elementary Run Club participants. If you have questions, please contact your Run Club leader.

Ballad Health, Bristol Tennessee City Schools, and Bristol Virginia Public Schools made this decision in accordance with current Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and World Health Organization guidelines regarding the novel coronavirus and large gatherings.

We will see you next year, runners and walkers!
text:
It is with sadness that we have decided to cancel what would have been the 8th Annual Power of Play 5K on April 25, 2020. Each school is in the process of issuing refunds to elementary Run Club participants. If you have questions, please contact your Run Club leader.

Ballad Health, Bristol Tennessee City Schools, and Bristol Virginia Public Schools made this decision in accordance with current Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and World Health Organization guidelines regarding the novel coronavirus and large gatherings.

We will see you next year, runners and walkers!

post_text: By today, every home should have received an invitation to participate in the 2020 Census. If you haven't done so already, you can respond for your home in one of three ways: online, by phone, or by mail. Go to https://2020census.gov/en/ways-to-respond.html for more information. Completing the Census is fast and easy, and it is a great at-home learning activity for the family! #EveryKidCounts #WeAreBTCS

post_text: www.census.gov
shared_text:
City of Bristol TN
March 31 at 9:01 AM ·

If you haven't already, take a few minutes TODAY to complete the 2020 Census. Information from the U.S. Census Bureau indicates that 35.2 percent of Bristol TN residents have responded, so we still have a long way to go. The information you provide determines how federal funds flow into our community, impacting everything from school lunches to highway funds. It only takes a few minutes, but it makes a huge impact. You can respond online, by phone, or by mail. Go to www.census.gov to learn more.

post_text: As many of you have commented on previous posts, principals and teachers have already begun reaching out to parents and students about plans for continuing educational activities during our closure for COVID-19. Those initial contacts will continue this week. Students in grades K-3 will get information from your school about a time to pick up instructional packets. Grades 4-12 will use digital resources. Teachers will primarily use Canvas to communicate with students. If a parent or student has a question about instruction, please contact your teacher. The BTCS web page for At-Home Learning information and resources may be accessed at tinyurl.com/btcslearnathomecovid19. #WeAreBTCS

post_text: TNPromise Update
shared_text:
Tennessee High School
March 22 at 7:48 PM ·

IMPORTANT SENIOR UPDATE: In light of recent CDC recommendations, TNAchieves has cancelled all in-school Tennessee Promise meetings for the year.

Students must now watch an online webinar to fulfill the mandatory meeting requirement.

The webinar MUST be watched prior to May 15th, 2020.

To access the webinar, please follow the directions below:
1. Students must go to this link: https://www.tfaforms.com/4810217
2. This link will ask you to sign in using your log in information.
3. Once you log in, you will be redirected to a YouTube seminar and much watch the 37 minute Tennessee Promise info video.
4. The website tracks how long you watch the video. Notification of your completion is only sent after the video is completed.

If you have trouble accessing your TN Promise account, you can either retrieve your password by requesting password assistance or by calling the TSAC Helpline (1-800-342-1663) to reset your account.
text:
TNPromise Update

Tennessee High School
March 22 at 7:48 PM ·

IMPORTANT SENIOR UPDATE: In light of recent CDC recommendations, TNAchieves has cancelled all in-school Tennessee Promise meetings for the year.

Students must now watch an online webinar to fulfill the mandatory meeting requirement.

The webinar MUST be watched prior to May 15th, 2020.

To access the webinar, please follow the directions below:
1. Students must go to this link: https://www.tfaforms.com/4810217
2. This link will ask you to sign in using your log in information.
3. Once you log in, you will be redirected to a YouTube seminar and much watch the 37 minute Tennessee Promise info video.
4. The website tracks how long you watch the video. Notification of your completion is only sent after the video is completed.

If you have trouble accessing your TN Promise account, you can either retrieve your password by requesting password assistance or by calling the TSAC Helpline (1-800-342-1663) to reset your account.

At this time, schools remain closed through Friday, April 3.

post_text:
Attention BTCS Families: Our friends in Kingsport City Schools have shared their School Closure Feeding Program information with us and invited our students to participate. Please visit the link in their post for more information.

Due to federal regulations, we are not allowed to begin our feeding program until after Spring Break. We will get more information out to you this week about our food distribution sites and hours beginning Monday, March 23. Thanks, Kingsport City Schools!
shared_text:
Kingsport City Schools
March 16 at 3:03 PM ·

UPDATE (3.18.20): Starting tomorrow, March 19th, we are adding additional bus delivery of free meals throughout our community. We'll now actually be running all of our regular bus routes during both breakfast and lunch loaded up with free meals for any child age 18 or under that would like one.

ATTN Kingsport City Schools Families: We wanted to provide you some important information regarding the feeding program that KCS will be offering during our school closure. FREE BREAKFAST and FREE LUNCH for children 18 and under will be available at most school locations and will be delivered by buses on all days we are closed for COVID-19 (Coronavirus), other than Spring Break, when federal regulations prevent us from doing that. One meal will be given per child, who does not need to be a KCS student. Please visit our website www.k12k.com for additional details.

post_text: THS students take the top honors in Business Battle 2020! #WeAreBTCS
shared_text:
Tennessee High School
March 9 at 4:14 PM ·

Tennessee High made a clean sweep today at the Business Battle Career Quest! Laura Lavinder won the first place prize including $1,000 for her "Grow My Garden" idea while Cole Haga and Mary Rose won second place and $500 for "Cole & Joel's Lawn Care and Odd Jobs." Maria Roth came in third place as an honorable mention with her business "NOLD" which makes New from OLD beach bags using recycled vinyl banners.

These students created these ideas and business plans on their own and presented to six local business people in a Shark Tank event at today's Business Battle 2020. We’re so proud of them! Please congratulate them!
text:
THS students take the top honors in Business Battle 2020! #WeAreBTCS

Tennessee High School
March 9 at 4:14 PM ·

Tennessee High made a clean sweep today at the Business Battle Career Quest! Laura Lavinder won the first place prize including $1,000 for her "Grow My Garden" idea while Cole Haga and Mary Rose won second place and $500 for "Cole & Joel's Lawn Care and Odd Jobs." Maria Roth came in third place as an honorable mention with her business "NOLD" which makes New from OLD beach bags using recycled vinyl banners.

These students created these ideas and business plans on their own and presented to six local business people in a Shark Tank event at today's Business Battle 2020. We’re so proud of them! Please congratulate them!

post_text: We are so proud of this talented group of students! #WeAreBTCS
shared_text:
Tennessee High School is at Tennessee High School.
March 9 at 10:38 AM · Bristol, TN ·

Congratulations to our SkillsUSA Digital Arts State winners! 🏆🎉
T-Shirt Design: Hayden Beverly – Gold (this qualifies for SkillsUSA Nationals!), Aidan Broyles – Silver; In Pin Design: Sophia Detrick – Silver; Kayleigh Hager – Bronze. This is the first time THS has competed and they won 4 out of 6 places! They will receive their awards at State SkillsUSA in Chattanooga April 20-22. Thank you to Mr. Shipley, our Digital Arts & Design CTE teacher!💯

post_text: Sports Physicals for the 2020-2021 school year will be available at Virginia High School on Saturday, May 16. The designated time for THS & VMS students is 9-10 a.m. In order to receive a physical, students must have a TSSAA Physical Form with the front page completed and signed by a parent/guardian. TSSAA Physical Forms can be picked up in the THS Athletic Office or VMS Main Office. In addition, forms may be downloaded and printed at https://tssaa.org/physical-forms. Forms will also be available at Virginia High if needed. The cost is $10. Cash only. No checks or credit/debit will be accepted.
text: Sports Physicals for the 2020-2021 school year will be available at Virginia High School on Saturday, May 16. The designated time for THS & VMS students is 9-10 a.m. In order to receive a physical, students must have a TSSAA Physical Form with the front page completed and signed by a parent/guardian. TSSAA Physical Forms can be picked up in the THS Athletic Office or VMS Main Office. In addition, forms may be downloaded and printed at https://tssaa.org/physical-forms. Forms will also be available at Virginia High if needed. The cost is $10. Cash only. No checks or credit/debit will be accepted.

post_text:
COVID-19 District Statement: In order to keep you informed, we wanted to update you on our current efforts regarding the coronavirus. Bristol Tennessee City Schools is actively monitoring the status of the virus in order to remain aware of current information. We are reviewing guidance from national organizations such as the Centers for Disease Control and local health departments and providers. We are working with school-based staff and public health experts in the development of operational plans to address any local impact that may take place. From preventative steps to potential response plans, we will continue to engage in these efforts as long as necessary to proactively plan for the safest possible environment for our students and staff.

For the most up-to-date information about the coronavirus, please go to www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html or call the Sullivan County Health Department at (423) 279-2777.

We are working with school-based staff and public health experts in the development of operational plans to address any local impact that may take place. From preventative steps to potential response plans, we will continue to engage in these efforts as long as necessary to proactively plan for the safest possible environment for our students and staff.

For the most up-to-date information about the coronavirus, please go to www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html or call the Sullivan County Health Department at (423) 279-2777.

post_text:
Student Voices: Juniors in Mr. Snyder’s class are having their voices heard through writing in the community section of today’s Bristol Herald Courier.

“I could not be prouder of my juniors this semester,” Mr. Snyder said. “They had a voice and wanted it heard; so they worked hard for roughly 1 1/2 weeks to research, write, correct, rewrite, and then shorten their letters to 300 words or less.”

Mr. Snyder would like to thank his student teacher, Ashley O’Dell, from King University for her leadership on the project! #WeAreBTCS

post_text: Wow! What a special opportunity! Congratulations Jaidyn! #WeAreBTCS
shared_text:
Holston View Elementary School
February 27 at 6:01 PM ·

INAUGURATION BOUND - Jaidyn W., a 6th grader at Holston View Elem. is headed to Washington D.C. in January 2021 to attend the Presidential Inauguration. She received an official invitation from the Presidential Inauguration Alumni Program based on the leadership STEM camp she participated in over the summer at Wake Forest. Mrs. Diana Bush, 5th grade teacher, nominated Jaidyn to participate in the Pathways to STEM camp due to her outstanding leadership and academic success. Jaidyn will spend 5 days in D.C. exploring the history and culture of the United States capital and attend the 2021 Presidential Inauguration. Congratulations Jaidyn for being recognized for your outstanding leadership!

UPDATE: If you change from the black lettering to the white lettering frame, you must select your profile picture again then add the new frame. Otherwise, the old frame will stay behind the new one.

We've had requests for a white lettering option of the new Facebook frame to use on profile pictures with dark backgrounds. It is now available, and you can search for it the same way as described in the previous post. It is called #wearebtcs2. Thanks to the THS Graphic Arts department for their help on this project! #WeAreBTCS

post_text:
UPDATE: Power has been restored at Holston View Elementary School! A big thank you to BTES for their hard work!

BTCS temporarily lost power at Holston View, Haynesfield, Vance, and THS. The power has been restored with the exception of Holston View. We would like to commend BTES for their rapid response and diligence to restore power quickly. We will continue to monitor the situation at Holston View and expect the power to be restored shortly. We want to thank our families for their patience and understanding.
text:
UPDATE: Power has been restored at Holston View Elementary School! A big thank you to BTES for their hard work!

BTCS temporarily lost power at Holston View, Haynesfield, Vance, and THS. The power has been restored with the exception of Holston View. We would like to commend BTES for their rapid response and diligence to restore power quickly. We will continue to monitor the situation at Holston View and expect the power to be restored shortly. We want to thank our families for their patience and understanding.

Schools will be closed on Friday, February 7.

Bristol Tennessee City Schools appreciates our school counselors! National School Counseling Week 2020 is February 3–7. The week, sponsored by the American School Counselor Association (ASCA), highlights the unique contribution of school counselors within U.S. school systems and the tremendous impact they can have in helping students
achieve school success and plan for a career. Be sure to take a moment and thank your school counselors!

post_text:
Tonight is the night! Come out to support your THS Vikings/Slater Wolves! Our basketball teams, along with Virginia High's teams, will celebrate Black History Month by representing the Slater Wolves (the Vikings) and the Douglass Demons (the Bearcats) at Virginia High School. The Vikings will be in Slater orange and black while the Bearcats will don the Douglass blue and gold.

Former players from Douglass and Slater will be recognized at 4 p.m. Gametimes: JV games at 1:00 and 2:30, Varsity Girls at 4:30, and Varsity Boys at 6:00.

post_text: Don't miss it! Douglass Demons vs. Slater Wolves
shared_text:
Tennessee High School
January 27 at 10:31 AM ·

This Saturday, Feb. 1, our basketball teams, along with Viriginia High's teams, will celebrate Black History month by representing the Slater Wolves (the Vikings) and the Douglass Demons (the Bearcats) at Virginia High School. The Vikings will be in Slater orange and black while the Bearcats will don the Douglass blue and gold.

Former players from Douglass and Slater will be recognized at 4:00. Gametimes: JV games at 1:00 and 2:30, Varsity Girls at 4:30, and Varsity Boys at 6:00. We hope to see you there!
text:

post_text: Congrats to Madison Wilson and Sydney Smith! The THS juniors took the top two spots in the 6th annual Black History Month-focused 2020 Eastman Oratorical Contest yesterday. Madison won first place and $1000, and Sydney won second place and $500. As the first-place orator, Madison will present her essay at 7:30 p.m. on Feb. 15 at the free Symphony of the Mountains Black History Month event, “Our Voices Rise Together,” at Eastman’s Toy F. Reid Employee Center. Read more https://www.btcs.org/about_us/what_s_new/eastman_oratorical_winners

post_text: Holston View students are looking beyond 2020 thanks to King University! Happy New Year from Holston View Elementary and Bristol Tennessee City Schools!
shared_text:
Holston View Elementary School
December 19, 2019 at 8:24 PM ·

COLLEGE BOUND... Our K-6 students experienced a taste of college life during the campus visit to King University. They cheered, played games, danced, and watched a men's and women's basketball game. Fourth through sixth grade students ate lunch in their cafeteria and toured a college dorm before heading to the game. Members of the women's basketball team visited with students during lunch and the admissions team talked to students about college life. Holston View students in the Bristol Tennessee Children's Choir kicked off the event by singing the national anthem. Thank you King University and Athletic Director, David Hicks, for your partnership and encouraging our students in the Bristol community to be college and career ready.
text:
Holston View students are looking beyond 2020 thanks to King University! Happy New Year from Holston View Elementary and Bristol Tennessee City Schools!

Fourth through sixth grade students ate lunch in their cafeteria and toured a college dorm before heading to the game. Members of the women's basketball team visited with students during lunch and the admissions team talked to students about college life. Holston View students in the Bristol Tennessee Children's Choir kicked off the event by singing the national anthem. Thank you King University and Athletic Director, David Hicks, for your partnership and encouraging our students in the Bristol community to be college and career ready.

shared_text:
Overmountain Chapter Trout Unlimited
December 26, 2019 at 6:10 PM ·

This past Monday, students from the Tennessee High Outdoor Club participated in field studies for their Two Streams Project. Accompanied by club advisors and OMTU volunteers, Mike and Lori Givney, students performed water chemistry testing, habitat assessment, stream flow analysis and macro-invertebrate identification. Students had a great time and came away with an even greater appreciation for our cold water resources and the work of our regional fisheries biologists. Thanks to OMTUs most recent License Plate Grant award, everyone was well attired in waders and boots!

Students had a great time and came away with an even greater appreciation for our cold water resources and the work of our regional fisheries biologists. Thanks to OMTUs most recent License Plate Grant award, everyone was well attired in waders and boots!

post_text: We want to thank our amazing community partners: Wallace Collision Center, Blue Ridge Color Company, and Shop Fix! Employees from these companies completely renovated the automotive paint booth at Tennessee High School this past Saturday. In addition, they installed equipment that the businesses have donated for the Career and Technical Education program at THS. As part of an ongoing partnership, their industry professionals will work with our students to train them on the use of the equipment and teach them real-world skills of the trade. Merry Christmas to these and all our community partners!
text: We want to thank our amazing community partners: Wallace Collision Center, Blue Ridge Color Company, and Shop Fix! Employees from these companies completely renovated the automotive paint booth at Tennessee High School this past Saturday. In addition, they installed equipment that the businesses have donated for the Career and Technical Education program at THS. As part of an ongoing partnership, their industry professionals will work with our students to train them on the use of the equipment and teach them real-world skills of the trade. Merry Christmas to these and all our community partners!

Check out the complete Arby's Classic bracket and see for yourself the exciting match-ups that you won't want to miss. The 37th annual tournament will be held December 26–31, 2019, with no play on Sunday, December 29.

Tickets for each session are $10 and are only available for purchase at the door for that particular session. Tournament passes are $50 and are available at the Tennessee High School Athletic Office and the Arby's restaurants in Bristol, TN & VA. Children under 5 are free. Find out more at www.arbysclassic.net!

post_text: A threat was posted on social media via Twitter earlier today, which tagged the Tennessee High School and Bristol Tennessee City Schools district Twitter accounts. Out of an abundance of caution, the Bristol Tennessee Police Department responded and conducted a search of Tennessee High. The school has now resumed a normal schedule, with the exception of third period testing will be moved to tomorrow. All threats are taken extremely seriously. The Bristol Tennessee Police Department is investigating.

post_text: Attention BTCS Families: Our district was notified today by the USDA of a public health alert which has been issued by the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advising consumers not to eat any romaine lettuce harvested from the Salinas, California, growing region due to illnesses caused by E. coli O157:H7. Immediately upon receipt of the alert, our school nutrition staff reviewed the labels of our lettuce inventory and discarded any potentially affected product. Prior to the alert, our school cafeterias did serve lettuce that was grown in the affected region of Salinas, California. E. coli is a gastrointestinal infection which causes symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, diarrhea, and fever. If your child exhibits any of these symptoms, please contact your medical care provider immediately. For more information on the alert and E. coli, please visit www.cdc.gov/ecoli/2019/o157h7-11-19/index.html.

post_text: Today was the first official gardening day for students at our newly relocated school garden! The garden, which is a partnership of BTCS and River's Way, was formerly located behind Vance Middle School and is now taking shape at its new location across from Tennessee High. This will allow gardening opportunities for our students with disabilities to be in closer proximity to the school. The supplies and materials needed to construct the new garden were provided by the BTCS Coordinated School Health grant. The BTCS Maintenance Department was instrumental in preparing the site and laying the foundation. Students will continue to prepare the beds this fall and be ready to plant in the spring!
text: Today was the first official gardening day for students at our newly relocated school garden! This will allow gardening opportunities for our students with disabilities to be in closer proximity to the school. The supplies and materials needed to construct the new garden were provided by the BTCS Coordinated School Health grant. The BTCS Maintenance Department was instrumental in preparing the site and laying the foundation. Students will continue to prepare the beds this fall and be ready to plant in the spring!

post_text: Our district was contacted earlier today by Bristol Virginia Public Schools regarding a report they received from one of their students. A Bristol Virginia Middle School student reported that an unknown individual posted a threat online indicating their intention to bring a weapon to school on Monday. No specific school or district was identified in the message. The Bristol Virginia Police Department is currently investigating. We have no reason to believe that the threat is tied to our district in any way; however, out of an abundance of caution, we have asked the Bristol Tennessee Police Department for additional police presence at our schools tomorrow, and our staff will be instructed to operate with a heightened level of security awareness. We will continue to be in touch with the police department and notify parents if there are further developments.

November 7, 2019 at 4:31 PM · Nashville, TN ·

Tennessee High School Health Science program has earned the Certified TN Pathway designation! 🎓🎉💯 Congratulations to CTE teachers Pam Moore and Michelle Phillips for providing quality courses, industry certifications (Emergency Medical Responder, Pharmacy Tech, OSHA10 Healthcare, CPR, and coming soon...CCMA), Clinical Internship with Ballad Health, and dual credit/ enrollment through NE State and ETSU! 🏆
text:
BTCS ... ensuring students achieve college and career readiness! Thanks and congratulations to all who made this happen for our students!

post_text: Mentors are needed to assist our seniors with the Tennessee Promise process! Tennessee Promise is a scholarship program focused on providing two years of tuition-free attendance at a community or technical college in Tennessee. post_text: Congratulations to our three 2019-2020 RTI2-B Model of Demonstration Schools! Anderson Elementary School has been selected as a Gold-level school, the highest achievement possible! Fairmount Elementary School has been selected as a Silver-level school. Holston View Elementary School has been selected as a Bronze-level school. Read more about the positive and proactive cultures these schools are creating through RTI2-B www.btcs.org/about_us/what_s_new/model_of_demonstration.

post_text: The Tennessee High School Mighty Viking Band (MVB) completed their marching season and brought home first place trophies in every category from the Appalachian Classic Band Competition in Blountville by sweeping the class 3A Category. The MVB won first place for color guard, drum major, percussion, music, effect, visual, and first in class 3A.

post_text:
Report cards for all students are available today Wednesday, October 16. Elementary students will continue to receive printed copies of report cards. However, for added convenience, parents may also access a digital copy of their child’s report card through the PowerSchool parent portal by clicking on the “Report Cards” link located in the menu on the left.

Vance and Tennessee High School student report cards will continue to only be available digitally this year via the PowerSchool Parent Portal. Parents of students in grades 7-12 who would like access to a printed copy of their child’s report card may do so in one of the following ways: 1) Print a copy from the PowerSchool Parent Portal. 2) Contact the school to pick-up a copy or have one sent home with their child.

post_text: The Jason Foundation is dedicated to the prevention of youth suicide. They partner with many of the nation's leading mental health experts to bring children, parents, and educators together to fight the "silent epidemic."
shared_text:
JASONFOUNDATION.COM
Parent Resource Program - jasonfoundation

The Jason Foundation, Inc. -Youth Suicide Prevention and Awareness
September 23, 2019 at 3:17 PM ·

There is a “Silent Epidemic” sweeping through our nation that claims an average of over 130 young lives each week. It knows no social, racial or economic barriers. This “Silent Epidemic” is youth suicide!

http://jasonfoundation.com/get-involved/parent/parent-resource-program/

post_text:
The Tennessee High School Mighty Viking Band will host 29 bands from numerous states, including several area high school marching bands, in the 68th annual Music in the Castle event on Saturday, October 5.

The cost to attend is only $8 for adults and $5 for students. Children 5 and under are free. Programs will be $6, with a ticket and program combination for only $12. Family members will also be able to purchase messages or band-o-grams to show support for students for $2 during the band festival.

Find out more: http://www.themightyvikingband.com/about-the-band/news/music-in-the-castle-2019.html

post_text:
Please join us on Thursday, September 19, for the Open House to celebrate the completion of our new field house in Stone Castle. The Open House will be begin at 5:00 p.m. prior to the Lady Vikings taking the field at 6:00 p.m. to play Dobyns-Bennett in girls’ soccer.

The following evening, Friday, September 20, at 7:00 p.m., prior to the Tennessee High and Morristown East football showdown, all donors to the field house project and special guests will be recognized. A ribbon cutting ceremony for the facility will also be held as the Vikings take the field for our first home game of the 2019 season. Kickoff is at 7:30 p.m.

Everyone is invited to join us for both of these special events to honor our beautiful, new state-of-the-art field house, and be sure to stay for the games to support our student-athletes!
text:

A ribbon cutting ceremony for the facility will also be held as the Vikings take the field for our first home game of the 2019 season. Kickoff is at 7:30 p.m.

post_text: Congratulations Ryan and Matthew!
shared_text:
Tennessee High School
September 12, 2019 at 6:23 PM ·

Congratulations to Ryan Lilly and Matthew Manno, who were named National Merit semifinalists this week.

Earlier this week, the National Merit Scholarship Corporation announced about 16,000 semifinalists Wednesday for the 65th annual National Merit Scholarship Program.

These students make up one percent of graduating seniors from across the nation and were chosen based on their PSAT results.

post_text: Please note temporary traffic pattern changes at Vance this week.
shared_text:
Vance Middle School
August 25, 2019 at 3:12 PM ·

TEMPORARY TRAFFIC PATTERN CHANGE (8/26-8/30)

Who: Cars in the Tremont Avenue Lane in the AM and Center Lane on Columbia in the PM

What: Due to the installation of our storm water drain, we need to pull our Tremont Lane of traffic (in the AM) and the middle lane of traffic (in the PM) straight across Edgemont.

Where: Intersection of Columbia Road and Edgemont Ave. The front of our building will be under construction and this will include a lane closure closest to our building on Edgemont. This will cause us to only have one lane turning right coming from Columbia Road to Edgemont Ave. Cars in the center lane on Columbia will have to go straight.

When: Monday, the 26th afternoon, through Friday, the 30th afternoon!

FACTS:
Times do not changes.

You will be directed where to go at the intersection of Columbia Road and Edgemont Avenue.

If you normally use the center lane and need to turn right onto Edgemont, make sure you get in the Columbia lane from the beginning.

shared_text:
Tennessee High Athletic Department
August 13, 2019 at 10:25 PM ·

On Sale Now

2019-20 VIP Passes & Reserved Football Seats

Student VIP - $55 This pass admits one student (K-12) to all regular season home games at THS & Vance. It does not include a reserved football seat.

Adult VIP - $85 This pass admits one adult to all regular season home games at THS & Vance as well as a reserve football seat and a parking space for varsity football games.

Senior Pass - $45 A senior pass gives anyone over 55 yrs of age admission to all regular season home games at THS & Vance. It does not include a reserved football seat.

Reserved Football Seat - $55 This pass is good for a reserve seat for the 5 varsity football home games.

If you have any questions contact Patty Feathers in the THS Athletic Office at feathersp@btcs.org.

post_text: New Dismissal Procedure at THS: Please note the following change in afternoon bus and car dismissal at Tennessee High School, effective immediately. In order to assist with traffic flow at Vance Middle School, all afternoon bus pick-up at Tennessee High will now take place in the back of the school on Southside Avenue. Therefore, all afternoon car riders must be picked up in front of the school. All bus numbers and load numbers will stay the same. Morning drop-off will not change.

post_text:
The InSideOut Initiative was the focus at a training as more than 60 BTCS coaches, school and district administrators, student representatives, school board members, and community sports leaders gathered today. The purpose of the InSideOut Initiative is to transform the current “win-at-all-costs” sports culture where the value is often defined by the scoreboard, into one that defines and promotes sports as a human growth experience. To find out more, go to
https://insideoutinitiative.org/ Tennessee High Athletic Department

post_text: Vance Middle School was evacuated this morning at approximately 11:30 a.m. due to a gas line break on Columbia Avenue adjacent to the school. There were less than 40 students and staff members inside the building at the time. All students and staff are safe and were immediately taken by bus to the BTCS Administration Building. We will continue to work closely with emergency personnel to determine when the building is cleared for re-occupancy. We anticipate that will be no later than tomorrow.

There were less than 40 students and staff members inside the building at the time. All students and staff are safe and were immediately taken by bus to the BTCS Administration Building. We will continue to work closely with emergency personnel to determine when the building is cleared for re-occupancy. We anticipate that will be no later than tomorrow.

post_text: Congratulations, to new Tennessee Online Public School Principal Dr. Kari Eubanks! Dr. Eubanks has been with TOPS since it opened its virtual doors in 2012. Beyond teaching English, she has worked side-by-side with administration and colleagues to shape and grow the school as a leader in online 9-12 education in Tennessee! Dr. Eubanks and her husband, Tim, are the proud parents to four dogs: Gracie Lou, Jasper, Frank, and Rigby.
text: Congratulations, to new Tennessee Online Public School Principal Dr. Kari Eubanks! Dr. Eubanks has been with TOPS since it opened its virtual doors in 2012. Beyond teaching English, she has worked side-by-side with administration and colleagues to shape and grow the school as a leader in online 9-12 education in Tennessee! Dr. Eubanks and her husband, Tim, are the proud parents to four dogs: Gracie Lou, Jasper, Frank, and Rigby.
